articles.headline: Republicans Yield as Confederate Flag Issue Roils Congress
articles.snippet: Amid a national debate, Republicans in Washington withdrew a bill that would have allowed Confederate symbols at national cemeteries.
articles.abstract: Amid a national debate, Republicans in Washington withdrew a bill that would have allowed Confederate symbols at national cemeteries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The anguished national debate over the future of the Confederate flag exploded on the House floor on Thursday as Democrats, led by black members from the South, beat back a push by Republicans to allow Confederate symbols at national cemeteries.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: Reinventing Google for a Mobile World
articles.snippet: As Google races to become as essential on smartphones as it is on desktops, competition is popping up throughout Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: As Google races to become as essential on smartphones as it is on desktops, competition is popping up throughout Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amit Singhal, Google’s search chief, oversees the 200 or so factors that determine where websites rank in the company’s search engine, which means he decides if your website lives or dies. His current challenge: figuring out how to spread that same fear and influence to mobile phones.

articles.headline: Stock Market Plunge in China Dents Communist Party’s Stature
articles.snippet: Investors have asked why the Communist Party and the government talked up the markets in recent months and then bumbled in efforts to prevent the rout.
articles.abstract: Investors have asked why the Communist Party and the government talked up the markets in recent months and then bumbled in efforts to prevent the rout.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Yu Xilin was obsessing on China’s plummeting stock market when he tumbled off his bicycle. But the accident did not sway his focus. While recovering in the hospital on Thursday from surgery for a broken ankle and shoulder, he was using his smartphone to track his shares.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: When Algorithms Discriminate
articles.snippet: Recent research has shown how some websites can produce results that perpetuate bias.
articles.abstract: Recent research has shown how some websites can produce results that perpetuate bias.
articles.lead_paragraph: The online world is shaped by forces beyond our control, determining the stories we read on Facebook, the people we meet on OkCupid and the search results we see on Google. Big data is used to make decisions about health care, employment, housing, education and policing.

articles.headline: Hacking of Government Computers Exposed 21.5 Million People
articles.snippet: Every person given a government background check for the last 15 years was probably affected, the Office of Personnel Management said.
articles.abstract: Every person given a government background check for the last 15 years was probably affected, the Office of Personnel Management said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday revealed that 21.5 million people were swept up in a colossal breach of government computer systems that was far more damaging than initially thought, resulting in the theft of a vast trove of personal information, including Social Security numbers and some fingerprints.

articles.headline: Why China’s Stock Market Bailout Just Might Work
articles.snippet: Unlike Japan in the 1990s, China has the motivation and the resources that may make government intervention in the markets succeed.
articles.abstract: Unlike Japan in the 1990s, China has the motivation and the resources that may make government intervention in the markets succeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Outside of China, the consensus among economists is overwhelming: The country’s efforts to prop up its plunging stock markets are doomed, the financial equivalent of King Canute trying to halt the incoming tide. But this being China, the conventional wisdom may turn out to be wrong.

articles.headline: Lionsgate Takes Fresh Approach to Promote ‘The Hunger Games’ at Comic-Con
articles.snippet: To publicize “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 2,” the film studio brought in 34 kettle drummers and Conan O’Brien.
articles.abstract: To publicize “The Hunger Games: Mockingjay — Part 2,” the film studio brought in 34 kettle drummers and Conan O’Brien.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Trot some stars onto a stage. Get a gushy blogger or aspiring comedian to ask canned questions. Dim the lights and show footage.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Facebook Said to Seek Music Video Licensing Deals
articles.snippet: If the company, which has been expanding its video offerings, can strike a deal with music labels, it could rival Google’s YouTube.
articles.abstract: If the company, which has been expanding its video offerings, can strike a deal with music labels, it could rival Google’s YouTube.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, Facebook has slowly encroached on YouTube’s territory as a go-to outlet for online video, showing popular content from publishers like BuzzFeed and Vice and a growing number of user-loaded clips. Now Facebook is considering going after another piece of YouTube’s signature turf: music videos.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Takata Says No to Fund for Victims of Defective Airbag
articles.snippet: The Japanese supplier of airbags, involved in the largest automotive recall in American history, says it will give the matter further consideration.
articles.abstract: The Japanese supplier of airbags, involved in the largest automotive recall in American history, says it will give the matter further consideration.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the recall of defective airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata has mushroomed and the death and injury toll has mounted, the company has come under increasing pressure to take more responsibility for its faulty products.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Jeb Bush Draws on Family Dynasty for Fund-Raising Efforts
articles.snippet: At first, Mr. Bush seemed unsure of how tightly to embrace the family mantle. But now he is bringing potential donors to Kennebunkport, Me.
articles.abstract: At first, Mr. Bush seemed unsure of how tightly to embrace the family mantle. But now he is bringing potential donors to Kennebunkport, Me.
articles.lead_paragraph: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me. — Maybe it was the sunset selfies on the lawn at Walker’s Point, the family compound, with the state flags of Texas and Maine fluttering in the salty breeze.

articles.headline: Web Chief Joshua Topolsky to Leave Bloomberg as Staff Tensions Surface
articles.snippet: Mr. Topolsky, who was hired last year to oversee Bloomberg’s web expansion, clashed with Michael Bloomberg, the founder.
articles.abstract: Mr. Topolsky, who was hired last year to oversee Bloomberg’s web expansion, clashed with Michael Bloomberg, the founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, after Michael Bloomberg reasserted control over the company he founded and began to scrutinize its online operations, he suggested in a meeting that perhaps Bloomberg — which makes the overwhelming majority of its money from desk terminals that provide financial data — did not need to have a website.

articles.headline: Why a Teenage Bank Teller May Have the Best Summer Job
articles.snippet: High school students who land banking positions learn crucial lessons about finance and interpersonal communications that can have far-reaching benefits.
articles.abstract: High school students who land banking positions learn crucial lessons about finance and interpersonal communications that can have far-reaching benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone should work as a bank teller at least once in their lives.
